title: Ticket #1545: Grid-type amazon can't submit to Eucalyptus
description:
Eucalyptus provides an EC2 interface. Thus, Condor-G should be able to interact with it via the amazon grid-type. However, several minor issues prevent this from working.

We're working with Brian Bockelman and others to get Condor to interact with the Magellan cluster at ANL (which uses Eucalyptus).

Tasks

  • Make SSL hostname check optional [DONE]
  • Update to newer EC2 WSDL [DONE]
  • Remove assumptions about image and instance names [DONE]
  • Fix SSL token names [DONE]

GSOAP SSL changes

The service credential for Magellan is a self-signed host certificate with a hostname of 'localhost'. This causes authentication to fail, as that doesn't match the name used by the amazon_gahp to connect to the server. This appears to be a default setup for Eucalyptus. To make interacting with such systems easier, we're adding a config parameter, SOAP_SSL_SKIP_HOST_CHECK. If set to True, then the amazon_gahp will instruct gsoap to skip the server hostname check. The default is False.

Brian Bockelman informs us that one of the security tokens in our soap messages has the wrong value. He suggests changing the call soap_wsse_add_BinarySecurityTokenX509(m_soap, "BinarySecurityToken", m_cert)) to soap_wsse_add_BinarySecurityTokenX509(m_soap, "X509Token", m_cert)).

WSDL Update

Condor is using an old revision of the EC2 WSDL, dated 2007-08-29. Brian Bockelman found that using that version doesn't work with Eucalyptus, but using the version from 2008-12-01 does. The differences are minor for the portions that Condor uses.

Naming Assumptions

The amazon_gahp checks whether image and instance ids match a particular pattern that Amazon's EC2 service is known to adhere to. Specifically, that image ids start with "ami-" and instance ids start with "i-". These patterns aren't part of the EC2 specificatoin, and Eucalyptus doesn't follow them. The checks should be removed.
